I.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
 
1.     The proposed transaction technical assistance (TA) will contribute to a sustainable and 
efficient energy sector in Turkmenistan through (i) a strategy and road map for energy efficiency; 
(ii) supporting transition to International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS) implementation;  
and (iii) transferring key project implementation knowledge in the areas of detailed engineering, 
procurement and environmental safeguards.  
 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Justification 
 
2.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has supported Turkmenistan’s energy sector for 
increased electric interconnections with neighboring countries and increased power exports. 
ADB’s country operations business plan for Turkmenistan, 2018–2019 emphasizes the following 
key areas of assistance: energy efficiency in generation, loss reduction in transmission, cross-
border power trade, and capacity building and institutional strengthening. 
 
3.  Energy efficiency traditionally has never been a priority in countries that are rich in energy 
resources, as domestic energy prices are very low. However, because of increasing focus on 
energy export, there is a growing interest to promote energy efficiency, as each unit of saved 
energy  represents  revenue  in  foreign  currency  if  the  unit  is  exported,  with  very  little  new 
investment. The opportunity for energy efficiency is also quite significant as most of the equipment 
were built and bought in the 70s, and some of them are operating in sub-optimal conditions. The 
scale of opportunity is also reflected by the fact that Turkmenistan is one of the countries with the 
highest energy intensity.  
 
4.  Absence  of  detailed  assessment  of  energy  efficiency  potential  and  a  plan  for 
implementation is essential to mainstream energy efficiency projects. Development of human 
capacity and understanding of the best available technologies in the entire power value chain—
generation, transmission, distribution, and end use appliances—is also an essential element.  
 
5.  Turkmenistan,  as  a  signatory  to  the  Paris  Agreement  has  developed  its  Intended 
Nationally Determined Contribution commitments. Energy efficiency measures and investment 
could enable the country in achieving those commitments. This technical assistance will help 
develop an energy efficiency strategy and road map to mainstream energy efficiency.  
 
6.  To tap into the international capital market, Turkemenenergo plans to move towards IFRS. 
Support from a team of technical experts is essential to identify actions for developing capacities 
(both human and systems) to move to IFRS and continue preparing financial statements with 
IFRS standards. The introduction of IFRS for Turkmenenergo will contribute to stronger financial 
management and lead to more sustainable development in Turkmenistan. 
 
7.  Turkmenenergo also have expressed interest to understand and learn from international 
best practices in engineering, procurement and environmental safeguards. Implementation of 
international best practices would improve implementation of current projects and enable effective 
development of future energy sector projects.

2      
 
B.  Outputs and Activities 
 
8.  Output 1: A strategy and road map for energy efficiency developed. Output 1 will 
enable policy makers a comprehensive understating of the energy efficiency potential in the 
country and develop strategies and plans to achieve those gains. The strategy and roadmap will 
propose step-by-step actions to be taken by the government, including the development of 
policies, laws, and regulations, together with priority areas for public and private investment. The 
consultants  will:  (i)  identify  energy  efficiency  projects  in  power  generation,  transmission, 
distribution, and end-use equipment, considering the best available technologies in each area; (ii) 
develop strategy, and a road map for implementing those projects and support from the regulatory 
framework; and (iii) conduct trainings and workshops on energy efficiency.  
 
9.  Output 2: International Financial Reporting Standards implementation supported.  
Output  2  will  support  government’s  own  decision1 to  implement  IFRS  in  all  state  owned 
enterprises. The TA will support Turkmenenergo transition to IFRS, and the consultants will: (i) 
prepare a diagnostics study of current practices; (ii) analyze gaps and identify key areas requiring 
changes between Turkmenistan’s national accounting standards (which are currently applied to 
Turkmenenergo’s  financial  statements)  and  IFRS;  (iii)  review,  recommend  and  establish 
investment  needed  for  Turkmenenergo’s  information  technology  systems  to  produce 
Turkmenenergo’s IFRS financial statements beginning in 2020; (iv) develop a detailed action plan 
for transition to full IFRS implementation from 2021; (v) provide training and capacity development 
plan for Turkmenenergo’s accounting staff to prepare and train others in their transition to IFRS; 
and (vi) support Turkmenenergo in the preparation of IFRS annual accounts and financial 
statements for 2018, 2019, and 2020. 
 
10.  Output 3: Project implementation knowledge transferred. Output 3 will supplement 
and improve the knowledge and capacity of the Ministry of Energy and Turkmenenergo have 
developed by implementing many large-scale power projects. This will enable them to develop 
bankable projects to be financed by international financiers. The consultants under the technical 
assistance will help MOE and Turkmenenergo to understand the gap, if any, between the 
international best practices and current practices in the energy sector. Knowledge transfer will be 
targeted  in  three  key  areas  of  project  implementation—engineering,  procurement  and 
environmental  safeguards—and  the  key  activities  will  include  technical  papers,  seminar, 
workshops and trainings.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
11.  The TA is estimated to cost $1.5 million, which will be financed on a grant basis by the 
Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction and administered by ADB. The key expenditure items are listed 
in Appendix 1. 
 
12.  The government will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, office 
and housing accommodation, office supplies, secretarial assistance, domestic transportation, and 
other in-kind contributions. The government was informed that approval of the TA does not 
commit ADB to finance any ensuing project. 
 
                                                
1 The presidential decree issued in December 2017.

3 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
13.  The TA will be implemented from November 2018 to May 2021. ADB will administer the 
TA through the Central and West Asia Department’s Energy Division, with support from the 
Turkmenistan Resident Mission. The Central and West Asia Department’s Energy Division will 
select, supervise, and recruit consultants. 
 
14.  All TA disbursement will be made following ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement 
Handbook  (2010,  as  amended  from  time  to  time).  The  implementation  arrangements  are 
summarized in Table 1.

15.  Consulting services. ADB will recruit the consultants following the ADB Procurement 
Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and the associated project administration instructions 
and/or staff instructions. An international consulting firm will be selected through the quality- and 
cost-based selection method using the simplified technical proposal. The ratio of quality against 
cost will be 90:10 to ensure the quality of the complex scope. Output-based and/or lump sum 
contracts will be considered for the engagement of the international consulting firm, individual 
consultants, and resource persons. In case there are experts not yet identified at this time, these 
experts will be recruited as individual consultants. A summary of consulting services required is 
provided in Table 2.
